title: Factorising with a Common Factor
text:
Factorising is the opposite of expanding. There are several method of factorising, but the most basic one involves indentifying common factors. For example, in the expression
\[
x^2 - 12x
\]
\(x\) is a common factor, and so
\[
x^2 - 12x = x(x - 12)
\]

title: Factorising with a Common Factor
text:
Factorising is the opposite of expanding. There are several method of factorising, but the most basic one involves indentifying common factors. For example, in the expression
\[
x^2 - 12x
\]
\(x\) is a common factor, and so
\[
x^2 - 12x = x(x - 12)
\]

title: Factorising with a Common Factor
text:
Example: More than One Factor
Sometimes, there is more than one common factor, and more than two terms:
\[
4x^2y + 8xy^2 + 4xy= 4xy(x + 2y + 1)
\]






Warning



When you take out all the factors from a term, there is a 1 left, not a 0. This is because when you factorise, you are dividing rather than subtracting, and anything divided by itself is 1.

title: Factorising with a Common Factor
text:
Test Your Understanding
Factorise completely:

\((3x^2 + 9x)\)

\((14t^2 - 21t^3)\)

\((8y + 28y^3)\)

\((-5h^3 - 40h^7)\)

title: Expanding Brackets
text:
Simplify algebraic expressions
Expand brackets
Solve equations in which the unknown appears on both sides

title: Expanding Brackets
text:
Simplify algebraic expressions
Expand brackets
Solve equations in which the unknown appears on both sides

title: Expanding Brackets
text:
Basic Principles
Algebra uses letters, often \(x\), to stand for numbers. Algebraic expressions can be treated in the same way as number expressions.

\(x + 3\) means “add three to the unknown number.”

\(3x\) means “3 times the unknown number.”

\(x^2\) means “square the unknown number.”

title: Expanding Brackets
text:
Example: Combining Like Terms
\[
a + 3ab - 4ba = a - ab
\]






Note



Note: \(ab = ba\), so \(3ab\) and \(-4ba\) are like terms.


\[
3p^3 + 2p^2 - 2p^3 + 5p^2 = (3p^3 - 2p^3) + (2p^2 + 5p^2) = p^3 + 7p^2
\]

title: Expanding Brackets
text:
Example: Multiplying Algebraic Terms
\[
4r \times 5t = 20rt
\]
\[
(3b)^2 \times 3b = 9b^2 \times 3b = 27b^3
\]






Tip




The multiplication sign is often not included between letters, e.g. \(3ab\) means \(3 \times a \times b\)
When multiplying, add like powers: \(3a^2b \times 2a^5b^4 = 6a^8b^5\). (Think of \(a\) as \(a^1\)).

title: Expanding Brackets
text:
Example: Expanding Brackets
\[
2(3 + x) = 2 \times 3 + 2 \times x = 6 + 2x
\]






Tip




Multiply each term inside by the outside term.
The multiplication sign is usually left out: \(3(x+y)\) means \(3 \times (x + y) = 3 \times x + 3 \times y = 3x + 3y\)
When multiplying, the number 1 is usually left out: \(-(2x+3)\) means \(-1 \times (2x+3) = (-1) \times (2x) + (-1) \times 3 = -2x + 3\)










Warning



Be very careful with negative signs outside a bracket.


\[
-2 \times (a-3) = (-2) \times a + (-2) \times (-3) = -2a + 6
\]

title: Expanding Brackets
text:
Example: Expanding with Indices
Expand \(5x^2(12x^3 + 4x^5)\)
\[
5x^2 \times 12x^3 + 5x^2 \times 4x^5 = 60x^5 + 20x^7
\]

title: Expanding Brackets
text:
Exercise 1
Pleae complete the worksheet

title: Expanding Brackets
text:
Example: Expanding Two Brackets
To expand \((x + 3)(x + 2)\), you can use the grid method. \[
\begin{array}{c|cc}
    & x & +2 \\ \hline
x   & x^2 & 2x \\
+3   & 3x  & 6
\end{array}
\]
Summing the terms on the inside and simplifying gives:
\[
x^2 + 3x + 2x +6 = x^2 + 5x + 6
\]

title: Expanding Brackets
text:
Example: Squared Bracket
A squared bracket is simply the same bracket twice. For example to expand \[
(2x+3)^2
\] the grid method is: \[
\begin{array}{c|cc}
    & 2x & +3 \\ \hline
2x  & 4x^2  & 6x \\
+3  & 6x    & 9
\end{array}
\]
Adding the terms on the inside and simplifying gives
\[
4x^2 + 12x + 9
\]

title: Expanding Brackets
text:
Test Your Understanding
Expand and simplify:

\((2y + 3)^2\)
\((4 + x)(3x - 1)\)
\((4a + 3)(4a - 3)\)
\((5 - 2a)(b - 6)\)

title: Expanding Brackets
text:
Exercise 2
Please complete the worksheet

title: Expanding Brackets
text:
Example: 2 \(\times\) 3 Grids
Expand and simplify \((x^2 + 6x - 3)(x-4)\)
\[
\begin{array}{c|cc}
     & x      & -4      \\ \hline
x^2  & x^3    & -4x^2   \\
6x   & 6x^2   & -24x    \\
-3   & -3x    & 12
\end{array}
\] \[\begin{align}
&x ^3 + 6x^2 - 3x - 4x^2 - 24x + 12 \\
=\ &x^3 + 2x^2 - 27x + 12
\end{align}\]

title: Expanding Brackets
text:
Test Your Understanding
Expand and simplify:

\((a - 3b + 2c)(a + b)\)

\((cd + 4c - 5d)(3e + 2f)\)

\((x^2 - x + 7)(2x + 3)\)

\((1 + 3x - 2x^2)(7x - 2)\)

title: Expanding Brackets
text:
Exercise 3
Please complete the worksheet.

title: Expanding Brackets
text:
Example: Triple Brackets
A three‐bracket expansion such as \((x+1)(x-3)(x+2)\) can be done in two grid‐method steps. First, expand \((x-3)(x+2)\):
\[
\begin{array}{c|cc}
& x   & +2 \\ \hline
x  & x^2 & 2x  \\
-3 & -3x & -6
\end{array}
\]
This gives a result of
\[
x^2 - x - 6
\]

Then expand \((x+1)(x^2 - x - 6)\) with a \(2 \times 3\) grid:
\[
\begin{array}{c|ccc}
& x^2    & -x     & -6   \\ \hline
x     & x^3    & -x^2   & -6x  \\
+1    & x^2    & -x     & -6
\end{array}
\]
So altogether \((x+1)(x-3)(x+2)=x^3-7x-6\)






Tip



The order you multiply the brackets does not matter.

title: Expanding Brackets
text:
Test Your Understanding
Expand and simplify:

\((x + 2)^3\)

\((2x + 1)(x - 1)^2\)

\((3 + y)(3 - y)^2\)

\((a - b x)^3\)

title: Expanding Brackets
text:
Exercise 4
Please complete the worksheet.

title: Welcome
text: Welcome to the Shell Mathematics course.

title: Linear Equations
text:
For each mathematical operation, there is an inverse operation.
\[
\Huge{\times \longleftrightarrow \div}
\] \[
\Huge{+ \longleftrightarrow -}
\]
To solve equations, we use inverse pairs to isolate the variable \(x\) for which we are trying to solve.

title: Linear Equations
text:
For each mathematical operation, there is an inverse operation.
\[
\Huge{\times \longleftrightarrow \div}
\] \[
\Huge{+ \longleftrightarrow -}
\]
To solve equations, we use inverse pairs to isolate the variable \(x\) for which we are trying to solve.

title: Linear Equations
text:
Example: One-Step Equations
To solve one-step equations, we simply use the relevant inverse pair:



\[\begin{align}
x + 3 &= 2 \\
x + 3 - 3 &= 2-3 \\
x &= -1
\end{align}\]
\[\begin{align}
y-5 &= 7 \\
y-5+5 &= 7+5 \\
y &= 12
\end{align}\]



\[\begin{align}
3u &= 12 \\
u \times 3 \div 3 &= 12 \div 3 \\
u &= 4
\end{align}\]
\[\begin{align}
v \div 2 &= 8 \\
v \div 2 \times 2 &= 8 \times 2 \\
v &= 16
\end{align}\]

title: Linear Equations
text:
Example: Two-Step Equations
When there is more than one step, it’s important to think about the order of operations. Drawing a diagram can help. For the equation \[
6x-2 = 16
\] we can draw the following diagram:





graph LR
    X((x))
    A["× 6"]
    B["−2"]
    C((16))

    X --> A --> B --> C






We need to work backwards using inverse pairs, so we first add 2 then divide by 6:
\[\begin{align}
6x-2+2 &= 16+2 \\
6x &= 18 \\
x \times 6 \div 6 &= 18 \div 6 \\
x &= 3
\end{align}\]

\[
\frac{x+3}{2} = 5
\] The diagram for this equation is





graph LR
    X((x))
    A["+3"]
    B["÷2"]
    C((5))

    X --> A --> B --> C






We need to work backwards using inverse pairs,
\[\begin{align}
\frac{x+3}{2} &= 5 \\
(x+3) \div 2 \times 2 &= 5 \times 2 \\
x+3 &= 10 \\
x+3-3 &= 10-3 \\
x &= 7
\end{align}\]

title: Linear Equations
text:
Test Your Understanding
Solve these equations:

\(5x-8=27\)$
\(\frac{x}{3}+4=9\)
\(\frac{x-3}{4}=1\)
\(3-2x = 7\)

title: Linear Equations
text:
Answers

\(5x-8=27 \Rightarrow x=7\)
\(\frac{x}{3}+4=9 \Rightarrow x=15\)
\(\frac{x-3}{4}=1 \Rightarrow x=7\)
\(3-2x = 7 \Rightarrow x=-2\)

title: Linear Equations
text:
Exercise 1
First question: \(3a-2=19\)

title: Linear Equations
text:
Example: Equations with Brackets
There are often two ways to solve these kinds of questions:


\[\begin{align}
3(x+7) &= 15 \\
3x + 21 &= 15 \\
3x &= -6 \\
x &= -2
\end{align}\]

\[\begin{align}
3(x+7) &= 15 \\
x+7 &= 5 \\
x &= -2
\end{align}\]


As you can see, expanding the brackets is not always the quickest method.

But sometimes if there is more than one bracket you need to expand the brackets and simplify first:
\[\begin{align}
5(x+2)-3(x-4) &= 28 \\
5x+10-3x+12 &= 28 \\
2x+22 &= 28 \\
2x &= 6 \\
x &= 3
\end{align}\]

title: Linear Equations
text:
Test Your Understanding
Solve these equations:

\(6(x-3)+5=29\)
\(8(x+2)-3(2x-1)=39\)

title: Linear Equations
text:
Answers

\(6(x-3)+5=29 \Rightarrow x=7\)
\(8(x+2)-3(2x-1)=39 \Rightarrow x=10\)

title: Linear Equations
text:
Exercise 2
First question: \(3(a+5)=36\)

title: Linear Equations
text:
Example: Equations with Fractions





graph LR
    X((h))
    A["×3"]
    B["÷2"]
    C[+3]
    D((12))

    X --> A --> B --> C --> D






We can use the same method for questions like this
\[\begin{align}
\frac{3h}{2}+3 &= 12 \\
\frac{3h}{2} &= 9 \\
h &= 6
\end{align}\]

There are two methods for questions like this:


Subtract 4 first:
\[\begin{align}
\frac{x}{3}+4 &= 9 \\
\frac{x}{3} &= 5 \\
x &= 15
\end{align}\]

Multiply by 3 first:
\[\begin{align}
\frac{x}{3}+4 &= 9 \\
x+12 &= 27 \\
x = 15
\end{align}\]








Warning



When you multiply both sides by 3 you must multiply every term by 3.

title: Linear Equations
text:
Test Your Understanding

\(\dfrac{x}{2} - 8 = 16\)
\(\dfrac{2x}{5} + 6 = 19\)

title: Linear Equations
text:
Answers

\(\dfrac{x}{2} - 8 = 16 \Rightarrow x=48\)
\(\dfrac{2x}{5} + 6 = 19 \Rightarrow x=32.5\)

title: Linear Equations
text:
Example: Multiplying First
\[
\frac{y-5}{3} = 4
\]
In some questions, you should multiply first because of the order of operations:





graph LR
    X((y))
    A["-5"]
    B["÷3"]
    C((4))

    X --> A --> B --> C






\[\begin{align}
\frac{y-5}{3} &= 4 \\
y - 5 &= 12 \\
y &= 17
\end{align}\]

title: Linear Equations
text:
Example: Fractions on Both Sides
If both sides of the equation are fractions, you can mutiply by the lowest common multiple of the denominators.
\[\begin{align}
\frac{3y+2}{3} &= \frac{2}{5} \\
(3y+2) \div 3 \times 15 &= 2 \div 5 \times 15 \\
(3y+2) \times 5 &= 2 \times 3 \\
15y + 10 &= 6 \\
15y &= -4 \\
y &= -\frac{4}{15}
\end{align}\]

title: Linear Equations
text:
Test Your Understanding

\(\dfrac{a+2}{3} = 4\)
\(\dfrac{g-4}{10} = 2\)
\(6 = \dfrac{2w+4}{3}\)
\(\dfrac{4r-3}{10} = \dfrac{1}{5}\)

title: Linear Equations
text:
Answers

\(\dfrac{a+2}{3} = 4 \Rightarrow a = 10\)
\(\dfrac{g-4}{10} = 2 \Rightarrow g = 24\)
\(6 = \dfrac{2w+4}{3} \Rightarrow w = 7\)
\(\dfrac{4r-3}{10} = \dfrac{1}{5} \Rightarrow r = \dfrac{5}{4}\)

title: Linear Equations
text:
Example: Variable on the Denominator
If the variable is on the denominator, the first step is always to multiply both sides of the equation by whatever the denominator is.
\[\begin{align}
\dfrac{7}{z} &= 42 \\
7 \div z \times z &= 42 \times z \\
7 &= 42z \\
7 \div 42 &= z \times 42 \div 42 \\
\dfrac{1}{6} &= z
\end{align}\]

This same method applies even when the denominator is more complex:
\[\begin{align}
\dfrac{7}{2v+3} &= 2 \\
7 \div (2v+3) \times (2v+3) &= 2 \times (2v+3) \\
7 &= 4v + 6 \\
1 &= 4v \\
\dfrac{1}{4} &= v
\end{align}\]

title: Linear Equations
text:
Example: Comparing Methods
With equations like \[
\dfrac{2}{v} + 2 = 9
\] there are two possible methods, but one has a high rate of error.


\[\begin{align}
\dfrac{2}{v}+2 &= 9\\
\dfrac{2}{v} &= 7 \\
2 &= 7v \\
\dfrac{2}{7} &= v
\end{align}\]

\[\begin{align}
\dfrac{2}{v}+2 &= 9 \\
2 + 2v &= 9v \\
2 &= 7v \\
\dfrac{2}{7} &= v
\end{align}\]








Warning



A very common error in the second method is to forget to multiply the 2 by \(v\). Remember, when you multiply both sides of an equation, you must multiply every term. Terms are expressions separated by a plus or minus.

title: Linear Equations
text:
Test Your Understanding

\(3 = \dfrac{15}{y}\)
\(\dfrac{8}{3p}=12\)
\(1=\dfrac{5}{y+2}\)
\(\dfrac{3}{3a-4}=5\)

title: Linear Equations
text:
Answers

\(3 = \dfrac{15}{y} \Rightarrow y=5\)
\(\dfrac{8}{3p}=12 \Rightarrow p=\dfrac{2}{9}\)
\(1=\dfrac{5}{y+2} \Rightarrow y=3\)
\(\dfrac{3}{3a-4}=5 \Rightarrow a=\dfrac{23}{15}\)

title: Linear Equations
text:
Exercise 3
First question: \(\dfrac{c}{2}=3\)

title: Linear Equations
text:
Example: Unknown on Both Sides
When the unknown appears on both sides, the goal is to combine those terms together so that the unknown appears only once. Then we can solve it in the same way as the previous examples. To do this, we can add or subtract one of the terms to both sides.
\[\begin{align}
11-2x &= 6x-13 \\
11-2x+2x &= 6x-13+2x \\
11 &= 8x-13 \\
24 &= 8x \\
3 &= x
\end{align}\]

If there are brackets, we can expand those first:
\[\begin{align}
2(x-4) &= 6x-28 \\
2x-8 &= 6x - 28 \\
-8 &= 4x - 28 \\
20 &= 4x \\
5 &= x
\end{align}\]

title: Linear Equations
text:
Test Your Understanding
Solve these equations:

\(8-3x = 4x+22\)
\(3(x+5) = 10x + 1\)
\(4(x+5) = 3(3x-5)\)

title: Linear Equations
text:
Answers

\(8-3x = 4x+22 \Rightarrow x=-2\)
\(3(x+5) = 10x + 1 \Rightarrow x=2\)
\(4(x+5) = 3(3x-5) \Rightarrow x=7\)

title: Linear Equations
text:
Exercise 4
Start with question 3: \(7x-2=4x+13\)
